user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_grow:
```c
int lfs_fs_grow(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err = LFS_LOCK(lfs->cfg);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_grow(%p, %"PRIu32")", (void*)lfs, block_count);

    err = lfs_fs_grow_(lfs, block_count);

    LFS_TRACE("lfs_fs_grow -> %d", err);
    LFS_UNLOCK(lfs->cfg);
    return err;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_fs_grow:
static int lfs_fs_grow_(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) {
    int err;

    if (block_count == lfs->block_count) {
        return 0;
    }

    
#ifndef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    // shrinking is not supported
    LFS_ASSERT(block_count >= lfs->block_count);
#endif
#ifdef LFS_SHRINKNONRELOCATING
    if (block_count < lfs->block_count) {
        err = lfs_fs_traverse_(lfs, lfs_shrink_checkblock, &block_count, true);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }
#endif

    lfs->block_count = block_count;

    // fetch the root
    lfs_mdir_t root;
    err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, &root, lfs->root);
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }

    // update the superblock
    lfs_superblock_t superblock;
    lfs_stag_t tag = lfs_dir_get(lfs, &root, LFS_MKTAG(0x7ff, 0x3ff, 0),
            LFS_MKTAG(LFS_TYPE_INLINESTRUCT, 0, sizeof(superblock)),
            &superblock);
    if (tag < 0) {
        return tag;
    }
    lfs_superblock_fromle32(&superblock);

    superblock.block_count = lfs->block_count;

    lfs_superblock_tole32(&superblock);
    err = lfs_dir_commit(lfs, &root, LFS_MKATTRS(
            {tag, &superblock}));
    if (err) {
        return err;
    }
    return 0;
}
...
#define LFS_LOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg,0)
...
#define LFS_UNLOCK(cfg) ((void)cfg)
...
#define LFS_TRACE(__VA_ARGS__) 
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Other fragments need not be investigated for Rule 17.8 because they do not modify function parameters themselves: the public wrapper lfs_fs_grow(lfs_t *lfs, lfs_size_t block_count) only reads its parameters and passes block_count by value to lfs_fs_grow_, and does not assign to either parameter. Calls to LFS_LOCK/LFS_UNLOCK and LFS_TRACE do not modify parameter variables (macros expand to (void)cfg,0 or (void)cfg or nothing). Assignments like lfs->block_count = block_count modify the object pointed to by the pointer parameter lfs (allowed by the rule), not the parameter variable itself. Local variables (root, superblock, tag, err) and their uses (including passing their addresses) are local-object modifications and do not alter function parameter variables. Other function calls shown (lfs_dir_fetch, lfs_dir_get, lfs_dir_commit) operate on objects or local variables and do not assign to the parameter variables in these fragments. Therefore the only places requiring investigation for possible modification of a function parameter are the declaration of the inner function (where the parameter exists) and the call that passes the address of that parameter (&block_count), which could allow the callee to modify the parameter variable.
